metadata.case_name: Madhu Wool Spinning Mills v. Respondent Company

facts.text: Appellants are a partnership firm named Madhu Wool Spinning Mills carried on by three Katakia brothers.

Respondent company has nominal capital of Rs. 10,00,000 divided into 2000 shares of Rs. 500 each; issued, subscribed and fully paid up capital Rs. 5,51,000 divided into 1103 equity shares of Rs. 500 each.
Three Katakia brothers held three shares in the company; other 1100 shares owned by N.C. Shah and group known as Bombay Traders (Nandkishore and Valia groups).

Prior to incorporation, agreement in May 1965 between Bombay Traders and appellants: Bombay Traders to pay Rs. 6,00,000 to appellants for acquisition of machinery and installation; erection expenses treated as loan to new company; machinery to be erected in shed of Ravi Industries Private Limited at monthly rent Rs. 3,100; advances convertible to equity.
Company incorporated in July 1965.
Appellants allege company adopted the pre-incorporation agreement; company denies adoption.
Appellants filed petition for winding up in January 1970 under s.433(c) Companies Act 1956 alleging inability to pay debts.

Appellants' claims: (A) Erection expenses Rs.1,14,344.97 + interest Rs.51,453.13 + commission Rs.51,453.12; (B) Compensation for shed occupation Rs.69,600 + interest Rs.7,857 + further interest Rs.21,576; (C) Invoices for 3 machines Rs.85,250 + interest Rs.37,596 + commission Rs.37,596.
Company failed to show indebtedness in books except Rs.72,556.01.
Company incurred losses up to 31 March 1969 of Rs.6,21,177.53 and further losses; stopped functioning since September 1969.

Company indebted to directors and firms Nandkishore Co. and Bhupendra Co.; total indebtedness including appellants' claim Rs.9,56,829.47; total liability including share capital Rs.14,98,923.33; assets Rs.8,81,171.96; current/liquid assets Rs.2,74,247.38.
Proposed sale of machinery at Rs.4,50,000 undervalued (market Rs.6,00,000); no board sanction; substratum disappeared; no possibility of profitable business; insolvent; just and equitable to wind up.
Single Judge of Bombay High Court made preliminary order accepting petition and issuing notice.
All shareholders and creditors aggregating Rs.7,50,000 supported company and opposed winding up.
Company disputes all claims except two invoices Rs.14,650 and Rs.36,000; books show Rs.72,556.01 due as on 31 March 1969; alleges settlement to Rs.14,850 payable from machinery sale proceeds.

Single Judge held claims disputed except Rs.72,556.01; company alleged settlement to Rs.14,850 denied by appellants; refused winding up; ordered deposit of Rs.72,556.01 in court; if no suit in 6 weeks, company withdraws; if suit filed, amount to suit.

High Court upheld Single Judge; claims strongly disputed: erection denied (no books entry, no privity, limitation barred, no demand); compensation denied (no entitlement, limitation, board resolution for rent Rs.4,250 to Ravi Industries); first invoice Rs.34,600 paid (receipt produced).
Katakia brothers resigned as directors August 1969; shares transferred December 1969; no demand letters till then; signed balance sheets not reflecting claims except two invoices.

Board resolution June 1969 for sale of machinery (Katakias present); Katakias sold shares to Valia group; letters 27 July 1969 no objection to sale; board 24 Oct 1969 recorded settlement Rs.14,850; agreement with R.K. Khanna 20 Dec 1969; AGM 8 Jan 1970 unanimously approved sale.
Creditors supporting company: Nandkishore Co. Rs.4,95,999; supporting appellants: Ravi Industries Rs.2,97,500 (rent), K.S. Patel Co. Rs.44,477.56 (erection, disputed).
Company credited Ravi Industries Rs.1,52,000 reducing rent claim to Rs.1,45,500; Ravi allegedly agreed to write off.

Balance sheet: share capital Rs.5,51,500; liabilities Rs.9,77,829.47; assets Rs.8,87,177.93; shortfall Rs.90,000; accumulated losses Rs.6,21,177.53; machinery book value Rs.6,07,544.58 to sell Rs.4,50,000 (shortfall Rs.1,50,000); total shortfall ~Rs.2,50,000.
Company intends to use sale proceeds for export business; objects include export, yarn buying/selling, commission agency; Nandkishore group (creditor Rs.4,95,000) to help.
Jayantilal Katakia (partner) Chairman till 22 Aug 1969; brothers directors till then.

legal_issues.text: Whether the respondent company is unable to pay its debts under s.433(c) Companies Act 1956 on the basis of appellants' disputed claims.
Whether the disputes raised by the company against appellants' claims are bona fide and substantial so as to preclude winding up.
Whether the substratum of the company has disappeared or it is just and equitable to wind up.
Whether wishes of majority creditors opposing winding up should prevail.

petitioner_arguments.text: Company liable for specific debts totaling over Rs.3 lakhs plus interest/commission; failed to record in books except Rs.72k; insolvent as liabilities exceed assets even after machinery sale; substratum gone as stopped business, no profitable prospect.
Proposed machinery sale unauthorized, at undervalue, no board sanction.

respondent_arguments.text: All claims disputed: no adoption of pre-incorp agreement; no privity; limitation barred; no demand; books show only Rs.72k (settled to Rs.14,850 payable from sale); first invoice paid (receipt); board resolution for rent to Ravi Industries.
Sale of machinery approved by board (Katakias present), shareholders unanimously; intends new profitable export business within objects; not abandoned business.

court_reasoning.text: Claims disputed in fact and law; prima facie evidence of no entitlement (no books, no privity, limitation, no demand, receipt for one invoice); Katakias as directors signed balance sheets not reflecting claims; dishonest taint.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Books do not show claims except Rs.72k; claims barred by limitation; no demand despite directorship.

court_reasoning.text: Well-settled: no winding up if debt bona fide disputed with substantial defence likely to succeed; court considers creditors' wishes; here majority creditors oppose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defence in good faith, substance, prima facie proof.

court_reasoning.text: Substratum not gone: company plans export business with sale proceeds; reasonable prospect despite losses; not ceased business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere losses do not destroy substratum without no future profit prospect.

court_reasoning.text: Petition abuse of process: improper motive to force groundless claims; presented just before machinery sale after resigning and selling shares.

holdings.text: If debt bona fide disputed with substantial defence, court will not wind up company.
Court regards wishes of majority creditors opposing winding up if reasonable.
Substratum gone requires proof of no reasonable profit prospect; mere losses insufficient.

precedents_cited.case_name: Amalgamated Commercial Traders Pvt. Ltd. v. A.K. Krishnaswami
precedents_cited.relevance: Non-payment of dividend bona fide disputed; no winding up.
No winding up where price not agreed, sum unreasonable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Re Brighton Club and Norfolk Hotel Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: No winding up where work not properly done.
Winding up if undisputed debt despite ability to pay.
Winding up if debt owed but amount disputed.
No winding up if no benefit to creditors; consider opposition.
Losses do not destroy substratum without no profit prospect.
Restrain petition as abuse despite insolvency if debts disputed.

statutes_cited.name: Companies Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Winding up on inability to pay debts; dividend payment within 3 months; ascertain creditors' wishes in winding up.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal upholding High Court and Single Judge orders refusing winding up of the company, as debts bona fide disputed, majority creditors opposed, substratum not lost, and petition abusive.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellants; company and supporting creditors awarded costs including one hearing fee.
outcome.costs: Appeal dismissed with costs to company and supporting creditors.

key_quotes.text: Two rules are well settled. First if the debt is bona fide disputed and the defence is a substantial one, the court will not wind up the company.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle applied to refuse winding up.

key_quotes.text: The alleged debts of the appellants are disputed, denied, doubted and at least in one instance proved to be dishonest by the production of a receipt granted by the appellants.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The court will regard the wishes of the majority in value of the creditors, and if, for some good reason, they object to a winding up order, the court in its discretion may refuse the order.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Palmer's Company Law; justifies considering creditors' opposition.
